Name: Porto Cesareo Marine Protected Area
MPA_objective: The capacity of the MPA to generate tourism value is given by the presence of resources of high naturalistic and historical-cultural value, including P. oceanica habitats, underwater and semi-dark caves, coralligenous, biocenosis of infralittoral algae, fish fauna, marine avifauna, beaches and coastal dunes.
Method: Cost Benefit Analysis

MPA_objective: The capacity of the MPA to generate tourism value is given by the presence of resources of high naturalistic and historical-cultural value, including P. oceanica habitats, underwater and semi-dark caves, coralligenous, biocenosis of infralittoral algae, fish fauna, marine avifauna, beaches and coastal dunes.

Name: Seaflower MPA
MPA_objective: 1) preservation, recovery, and long-term maintenance of species, biodiversity, ecosystems, and other natural values including special habitats; 2) promotion of sound management practices to ensure long-term sustainable use of coastal and marine resources; 3) equitable distribution of economic and social benefits to enhance local development; 4) protection of rights pertaining to historical use; and 5) education to promote stewardship and active community involvement in management.
Method: Gathered from literature & communication with funding agencies/MPA managers

Name: Coral Sea MPA
MPA_objective:
Protect examples of the region’s marine ecosystems
and biodiversity (support critical nesting sites for the green turtle and renowned for its diversity of big predatory fish and sharks)
Method: Sum of compensation payments made to affected individual businesses (based on present and future profitability of fishing businesses and value of fishery assets)
Reference: Hunt, C. (2013). Benefits and opportunity costs of Australia’s Coral Sea marine protected area: A precautionary tale. Marine Policy, 39, 352–360. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.marpol.2012.12.012

Name: Coral Sea MPA
MPA_objective:
Protect examples of the region’s marine ecosystems
and biodiversity (support critical nesting sites for the green turtle and renowned for its diversity of big predatory fish and sharks)
Method: Surveyed experts in manangement

Name: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Cairns Section)
MPA_objective: The major activities in this section of the park are tourism, commercial fishing in- cluding trawling, and recreational boating and fishing. Clearly a range of tools--education, enforcement, plan- ning, research, and monitoring--are required to meet the multiple-use management objectives of such a vast area and highly diverse group of stakeholders. When management commenced, education and enforcement were recognized as important tools in meeting several management objectives, especially increasing the aware- ness of the park's existence and values, improving zon- ing compliance, and gaining community support for management activities.
Method: The money spent for education is the corresponding percentage of salaries and associated costs plus all project requisite costs. The total annual cost of GBRMPA education programs including salaries were taken from annual reports
Reference: Alder, J. (1996). Costs and Effectiveness of Education and Enforcement, Cairns Section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Environmental Management (New York), 20(4), 541–551. https://doi.org/10.1007/BF01474654

Name: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Cairns Section)
MPA_objective: The major activities in this section of the park are tourism, commercial fishing in- cluding trawling, and recreational boating and fishing. Clearly a range of tools--education, enforcement, plan- ning, research, and monitoring--are required to meet the multiple-use management objectives of such a vast area and highly diverse group of stakeholders. When management commenced, education and enforcement were recognized as important tools in meeting several management objectives, especially increasing the aware- ness of the park's existence and values, improving zon- ing compliance, and gaining community support for management activities.
Method: Money spent on enforcement is the percentage of salaries and associated costs plus 50% of vessel running costs, and in addition, air surveillance costs as detailed in annual reports. Total vessel running costs were prorated since vessels are also used for other functions, such as resource assessment and monitoring.

Name: Komodo National Park
MPA_objective: Preserve the park's biodiversity, including the Komodo dragon, marine habitats, and terrestrial habitats
Method: Enforcement-related expenses were calculated by sum- ming costs of operating floating ranger stations, speed boat support, fuel, maintenance costs, Park staff salaries, food costs, and stipends for the patrolling rangers. This base value was increased each year by 5% to account for inflation when calculating future expenses (S. Mangub- hai, unpublished data). Itemized figures from the Park’s workplan and budgets were used, but only aggregated costs are reported here because staff salaries and ranger stipends are not publicly released.
Reference: Haisfield, K. M., Fox, H. E., Yen, S., Mangubhai, S., & Mous, P. J. (2010). An ounce of prevention: cost-effectiveness of coral reef rehabilitation relative to enforcement. Conservation Letters, 3(4), 243–250. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1755-263X.2010.00104.x

Name: Komodo National Park
MPA_objective: Preserve the park's biodiversity, including the Komodo dragon, marine habitats, and terrestrial habitats
Method: Enforcement-related expenses were calculated by sum- ming costs of operating floating ranger stations, speed boat support, fuel, maintenance costs, Park staff salaries, food costs, and stipends for the patrolling rangers. This base value was increased each year by 5% to account for inflation when calculating future expenses (S. Mangub- hai, unpublished data). Itemized figures from the Park’s workplan and budgets were used, but only aggregated costs are reported here because staff salaries and ranger stipends are not publicly released.

Name: Taputeranga marine reserve
MPA_objective: A marine reserve here was proposed in 1987 to protect culturally important sites, diverse plants and animals, undersea reefs and biological oddities for restoration, recreation and study
Objective_category: Marine conservation, sustainable use, cultural value
Method:
Costs incurred in the consultation pro-
cess prior to the MR being gazetted
Reference: Rojas-Nazar, U. A., Cullen, R., Gardner, J. P. A., & Bell, J. J. (2015). Marine reserve establishment and on-going management costs: A case study from New Zealand. Marine Policy, 60, 216–224. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.marpol.2015.06.029

Name: Taputeranga marine reserve
MPA_objective: A marine reserve here was proposed in 1987 to protect culturally important sites, diverse plants and animals, undersea reefs and biological oddities for restoration, recreation and study
Method:
Cost information for three years for the five MRs (2008/09,
2009/10 and 2010/11) were obtained, which included salaries,
operating costs, and where possible, information about surveys
and boat costs.

Name:
Kapiti marine
reserve
MPA_objective: The primary objective of the Kapiti Marine Reserve is to preserve the natural marine environment around Kapiti Island, New Zealand, by protecting its diverse marine life and habitats through a "no-take" zone, allowing for scientific study and the regeneration of fish and shellfish populations; essentially acting as a conservation area for marine ecosystems and biodiversity.
Method:
Cost information for three years for the five MRs (2008/09,
2009/10 and 2010/11) were obtained, which included salaries,
operating costs, and where possible, information about surveys
and boat costs.

Name: Kofiau and Boo Islands Marine Protected Area
MPA_objective: Provides food and livelihoods to 2000 people living in five villages on the larger island of Kofia
Method: Cost from Leisher et al., 2012
Notes: Cost leading up to and during the creation of the protected areas around Kofiau and around the nearby island of Misool
Reference: Leisher et al., 2012. Measuring the benefits and costs of community education and outreach in marine protected areas

Name: Montego Bay Marine Park
MPA_objective: Developing user regulations that will create activity patterns consistent with the principle of sustainable usage
Method: Interview of the park's authorities
Which_zones: category II protected area means simply that users are encouraged, in other words, expected to abide by rules and regulations
Reference: Reid-Grant, K., & Bhat, M. G. (2009). Financing marine protected areas in Jamaica: An exploratory study. Marine Policy, 33(1), 128-136. https://doi-org.elibrary.jcu.edu.au/10.1016/j.marpol.2008.05.004

Name: Isole Ciclopi
MPA_objective: Its mission is to protect and manage a small but significative area of the sicilan sea, with remarkable geological and marine environmental values.
Method: Gathered from previous literatures and conversion factors used in this study are documented.
Which_zones: 3 zones: integral reserve zone, general reserve, and partial reserve
Reference: Toscano, F., Alongi, G., Conti, E., Turnaturi, R., & Mulder, C. (2020). Capitalizing the blue world: What can we learn from an Eastern Mediterranean case study?. Ecological Indicators, 115, 106420.

Name: Tortugas Ecological Reserve
MPA_objective: The intent of the TER is to preserve spccies richness and stock health and to conserve commercial and recreational stock stability
Method: Information was gathered  from U.S. Dept. of Commerce
Notes: A zone apart of the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary
Reference: Cook, G. S., & Heinen, J. T. (2005). On the uncertain costs and tenuous benefits of Marine reserves: a case study of the Tortugas Ecological Reserve, South Florida, USA. Natural Areas Journal, 25(4), 390-396.

Name: Apo  Island Marine Sanctuary
MPA_objective: To protect biodiversity and also to allow the build-up of fish abundance and biomass in order to export fish to the areas outside of the reserves.
Method: Calculated based on contribution from volunteers of the barangay and municipal government, Silliman University, the Department of Environment and Natural Resources and visitors donations.
Reference: White, A. T., Vogt, H. P., & Arin, T. (2000). Philippine Coral Reefs Under Threat: The Economic Losses Caused by Reef Destruction. Marine Pollution Bulletin, 40(7), 598–605. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0025-326X(00)00022-9

Name: Apo  Island Marine Sanctuary
MPA_objective: To protect biodiversity and also to allow the build-up of fish abundance and biomass in order to export fish to the areas outside of the reserves.
Method: Calculated based on the contributions from Silliman University, a foreign donor, and outside volunteers
Reference: White, A. T., Vogt, H. P., & Arin, T. (2000). Philippine Coral Reefs Under Threat: The Economic Losses Caused by Reef Destruction. Marine Pollution Bulletin, 40(7), 598–605. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0025-326X(00)00022-9

Name: Great Barrier Reef Marine Reserve
MPA_objective: To maintain biological diversity, protect marine habitats, and to restore depleted or threatened species.
Method: From another paper (Macintosh et al. 2010. Dealing with interests displaced by marine protected areas: A case study on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Structural Adjustment Package.Ocean and Coastal Management 53 (9): 581-588
Reference: Libecap, G.D. Advancing ocean ecosystem conservation via property rights, rather than marine protected areas (MPAs). Maritime Studies 23, 15 (2024). https://doi.org/10.1007/s40152-024-00358-0

Name: Regno di Nettuno
MPA_objective: To pursue the environmental protection and enhancement of the sea surrounding the islands of Ischia, Procida and Vivara, in the Gulf of Naples
Method: Systematic Costs Assessment
Reference: Appolloni, L., Sandulli, R., Vetrano, G., & Russo, G. F. (2018). A new approach to assess marine opportunity costs and monetary values-in-use for spatial planning and conservation; the case study of Gulf of Naples, Mediterranean Sea, Italy. Ocean & Coastal Management, 152, 135–144. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ocecoaman.2017.11.023

Name: Underwater Parks of Gaiola
MPA_objective: Protecting and preserving the area's rich underwater archaeological heritage, including ancient Roman ruins, while also promoting marine life conservation and providing educational opportunities for researchers and visitors through controlled access and scientific study
Method: Systematic Costs Assessment
Reference: Appolloni, L., Sandulli, R., Vetrano, G., & Russo, G. F. (2018). A new approach to assess marine opportunity costs and monetary values-in-use for spatial planning and conservation; the case study of Gulf of Naples, Mediterranean Sea, Italy. Ocean & Coastal Management, 152, 135–144. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ocecoaman.2017.11.023

Name: Underwater Parks of Baia
MPA_objective: Protecting and preserving the area's rich underwater archaeological heritage, including ancient Roman ruins, while also promoting marine life conservation and providing educational opportunities for researchers and visitors through controlled access and scientific study
Method: Systematic Costs Assessment
Reference: Appolloni, L., Sandulli, R., Vetrano, G., & Russo, G. F. (2018). A new approach to assess marine opportunity costs and monetary values-in-use for spatial planning and conservation; the case study of Gulf of Naples, Mediterranean Sea, Italy. Ocean & Coastal Management, 152, 135–144. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ocecoaman.2017.11.023

Name: Punta Campanella
MPA_objective: To preserve one of the most beautiful and rich stretches of Italian coast from a naturalistic point of view, both for the terrestrial and for the underwater environment
Method: Systematic Costs Assessment
Reference: Appolloni, L., Sandulli, R., Vetrano, G., & Russo, G. F. (2018). A new approach to assess marine opportunity costs and monetary values-in-use for spatial planning and conservation; the case study of Gulf of Naples, Mediterranean Sea, Italy. Ocean & Coastal Management, 152, 135–144. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ocecoaman.2017.11.023

Name: Mnemba-Chwaka Bay Marine Conservation Area (MIMCA)
MPA_objective:
primarily to enhance conservation of the marine resources
in an area under pressure from local fishers and tourism
Method: Information provided by reference (World Bank. Restructuring paper on a proposed project restructuring of marine and coastal environment management project: approved on July 21, 2005 to The United Republic of Tanzania. Washington DC: The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development/The World Bank; 2012)
Cost_type: Loan from the World Bank and GEF grant for establishment costs
Reference: Gustavsson, M., Lindström, L., Jiddawi, N. S., & de la Torre-Castro, M. (2014). Procedural and distributive justice in a community-based managed marine protected area in Zanzibar, Tanzania. Marine Policy, 46, 91-100.

Name: Marine Life Protection Act (MLPA) in California
MPA_objective: 6 goals: To protect natural diversity/abundance of marine life. To help sustain, conserve, and protect marine life including of economic value. To improve recreational, educational, and study opportunities. To protect marine natural heritage. To ensure effective management measures. To ensure that state's MPAs designed and managed as network.
Method: Information was gathered from Resources Legacy Fund Foundation (RLFF)
Cost_type: private charitable foundation funds supported the development of the draft master plan
Notes: The MLPA is a network of 124 MPAs, across the California coast.
Reference: Gleason, M., Fox, E., Ashcraft, S., Vasques, J., Whiteman, E., Serpa, P., ... & Wiseman, K. (2013). Designing a network of marine protected areas in California: achievements, costs, lessons learned, and challenges ahead. Ocean & Coastal Management, 74, 90-101.

Name: Marine Life Protection Act (MLPA) in California
MPA_objective: 6 goals: To protect natural diversity/abundance of marine life. To help sustain, conserve, and protect marine life including of economic value. To improve recreational, educational, and study opportunities. To protect marine natural heritage. To ensure effective management measures. To ensure that state's MPAs designed and managed as network.
Method: Information was gathered from Resources Legacy Fund Foundation (RLFF)
Reference: Gleason, M., Fox, E., Ashcraft, S., Vasques, J., Whiteman, E., Serpa, P., ... & Wiseman, K. (2013). Designing a network of marine protected areas in California: achievements, costs, lessons learned, and challenges ahead. Ocean & Coastal Management, 74, 90-101.

Name: Kosterhavet marine national park
MPA_objective: to protect the area's unique marine environment, as well as to ensure the survival of its cultural heritage
Method: Financed by the Swefish Environmental Protection Agency, information gathered from an interviewee
Cost_type: Annual park budget to cover costs of management, maintenance, monitoring and reporting.
Reference: Pantzar, M. (2020). Balancing rural development and robust nature conservation–Lessons learnt from Kosterhavet Marine National Park, Sweden. In Marine Protected Areas (pp. 299-328). Elsevier.

Name: Nha Trang Bay Marine Protected Area
MPA_objective: to enable local island communities to improve their livelihoods and, in partnership with other stakeholders, effectively protect and sustainably manage the marine biodiversity at NTB as a model for collaborative MPA management in Vietnam”
Method: Sourced from Nha Trang Bay Marine Protected Area Authority
Reference: Xuan, B. B., Sandorf, E. D., & Aanesen, M. (2017). Informing management strategies for a reserve: Results from a discrete choice experiment survey. Ocean & Coastal Management, 145, 35-43.

Name: Nha Trang Bay Marine Protected Area
MPA_objective: to enable local island communities to improve their livelihoods and, in partnership with other stakeholders, effectively protect and sustainably manage the marine biodiversity at NTB as a model for collaborative MPA management in Vietnam”
Method: From a reference (Nam et al., 2005)

Name: Coral Sea Marine Park
Method: Application of Balmford et al. model
Notes: A global statistical model (Balmford et al. 2004), in which the cost of management is predicted by MPA area, distance from inhabited land, and purchasing power parity; (2) new statistical modeling using data on management costs of Australian Commonwealth Government MPAs; and (3) expert-based assessment
Reference: Ban, N. C., Adams, V., Pressey, R. L., & Hicks, J. (2011). Promise and problems for estimating management costs of marine protected areas. Conservation Letters, 4(3), 241-252.  https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1755-263X.2011.00171.x

Name: Coral Sea Marine Park
Method: Statistical model using Australian MPA data

Name: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park
MPA_objective: Provide for the long-term protection, ecologically sustainable use, understanding and enjoyment of the Great Barrier Reef for all Australians and the international community through the care and development of the Marine Park.
Method: Referenced in (McCook et al., 2010)
Cost_type: management costs after rezoning plan of 2004
Reference: Leenhardt, P., Cazalet, B., Salvat, B., Claudet, J., & Feral, F. (2013). The rise of large-scale marine protected areas: Conservation or geopolitics?. Ocean & Coastal Management, 85, 112-118.
